Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have been widely applied as industrial catalysts for methanol synthesis from syngas, but suffers low activity for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. This study establishes highly active Cu catalysts through modulation of the composite of Al2O3 and ZrO2 in Cu/ZnO-based catalysts. The composition of Al2O3 and ZrO2 impacts the Cu dispersion, exposed surface area of Cu, the Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio and surface basicity. An appropriate content of Al2O3 and ZrO2 presents the higher Cu surface area, desirable ratio of Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) and moderate-strong basic sites for effective CO2 adsorption/activation, giving rise to higher space-time yield of methanol (up to 648 gCH3OH·kgcat −1·h−1) than the commercial Cu catalyst. STY of methanol can be correlated with Cu surface area and Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio under the investigated conditions. The mechanistic analysis demonstrates that surface formate and methoxy species are the major intermediates. The methanol formation principally follows the formate-methoxy intermediate pathway. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol synthesis Cu Oxide promoter Al2O3 and ZrO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A rapid increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration resulting from burning fossil fuels has caused a series of environmental problems (e.g., ocean acidification, global temperature rise, and extreme weather), rendering the reduction of CO2 emission necessary [1,2]. As an abundant carbon resource, chemical utilization of CO2 on industrial scale mainly relies on production of urea, salicylic acid, carbonate esters, and etc. [3]. Conversion of CO2 via catalytic hydrogenation is a potential route for industrial manufacturing of methanol, olefin, gasoline, etc [4,5]. Methanol is an important commodity chemical that can be used as an intermediate for synthesis of high value-added products (e.g., formaldehyde, dimethyl ether and acetic acid) [6–8], and can also be used directly as a low-carbon fuel [9]. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is considered to be one of the most promising routes for large-scale utilization of CO2, which has attracted great attention. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is an exothermic reaction (CO2 + 3 H2 → CH3OH, ΔH0 = −49.5 kJ/mol) [10], low temperature and high pressure are conducive to the conversion of CO2 to methanol. However, due to the inertness of CO2, it is difficult to kinetically activate/convert CO2 at low temperature. At high temperature, reverse water gas shift reaction occurs to produce CO as a byproduct (CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O, ΔH0 = 41.2 kJ/mol) [11]. Thus, it is important to develop a catalyst with high activity and selectivity at low temperature. Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have been widely used in the industrial production of methanol from synthesis gas mixtures (H2/CO2/CO) that are featured with a large Cu/Zn ratio (in most cases up to 2) and a low content of Al2O3 (usually up to 10% Al2O3) [10,12,13]. Cu has been considered to be the primarily active component and one important key to high performance is a large accessible Cu surface area that has been reported to show a linear correlation with the conversion rate of CO2 [14,15]. It has also been reported that the CO2 conversion rate increases with the increase of Cu surface area, but this relationship is not linear [16]. Some studies have shown that both Cu0 and Cu+ species are involved in catalyzing the reaction [17–19]. Sun et al. [16] reported that the adsorption and dissociation of H2 occurred on Cu0, and the presence of Cu+ was conducive to stabilizing the intermediate CH3O* that promoted further hydrogenation to methanol. Dong et al. [20] found that an appropriate Cu0/Cu+ ratio (ca. 9) was conducive to the reaction. Toyir et al. [21] optimized the Cu0/Cu+ ratio by adding Ga to the Cu-based catalyst, yielding improved catalytic performance. The understanding on the catalytic role of ZnO is divergent. It has been proposed that ZnO acts as a physical spacer between Cu nanoparticles, promoting the dispersion of Cu [22]; while Cu-ZnO interaction in either CuZn alloy or Cu-ZnO interface is involved in the formation of active sites [12]. Al2O3 and ZrO2 are the two most commonly used oxide promoters in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. Refractory oxide Al2O3 is a structural promoter [10]. The presence of Al2O3 can increase the distribution of Cu and the surface area [23]. Gao et al. [24] reported an appropriate amount of ZrO2 in CuO/ZnO/Al2O3/ZrO2 can increase the surface area of Cu and the surface basicity, generating high activity and selectivity. Sun et al. [16] adjusted the ratio of Cu0/Cu+ and promoted the dispersion of Cu by adding different contents of ZrO2 in Cu/ZnO, so as to optimize the catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In the CuO/ZnO/Al2O3/ZrO2 catalysts, Al2O3 and ZrO2 can impact on the catalyst structure and surface characteristics. It is necessary to understand the influence of the composition of mixed oxide (Al2O3 and ZrO2) on the catalyst structure, reactant adsorption/activation and further the catalytic behavior in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In this study, a series of CuO/ZnO/Al2O3/ZrO2 catalysts with different contents of Al2O3 and ZrO2 were constructed by three-step precipitation based on an optimized CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. The influence of ZrO2 and Al2O3 on the structure/surface properties and catalytic performance were studied to elucidate the structure-activity relationship. The evolution of surface intermediates during the reaction was studied by in situ spectroscopy to explore the reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The reagents such as Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O, NaOH, NaCO3 and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O are of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The series of CuO/ZnO/Al2O3/ZrO2 catalysts with fixed mass fraction of CuO (60%) and ZnO (30%) but different contents of Al2O3 (0, 3%, 5%, 8% and 10%) and ZrO2 (10%, 7%, 5%, 2% and 0) were synthesized by three-step precipitation. Three kinds of aqueous nitrate solution (A, B and C) were prepared. Solution A (0.15 M) contains 20% of zinc nitrate and of aluminum nitrate. Copper nitrate with the remaining zinc nitrate and of aluminum nitrate made solution B (0.15 M). Solution C (0.05 M) is zirconium nitrate. Solution A and solution B were precipitated with NaCO3 (0.1 M) at 70 °C and pH = 7±0.2, respectively. Solution C was precipitated by NaOH (0.1 M) at 70 °C and pH = 9±0.2. After precipitation, the suspension was mixed under stirring and aged at 70 °C for 4 h. The precipitate was washed three times with deionized water, dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and then calcined at 320 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace. According to the content of ZrO2, the catalyst was named as CZA, CZA-xZrO2 (x represents the mass fraction of ZrO2, x = 2%, 5% and 7%) and CZZ. The catalyst with mass ratio of CuO: ZnO: Al2O3: ZrO2 of 60:30:3:7 was also prepared by coprecipitation. The nitrate solution was precipitated with NaCO3 (1 M) at 70 °C and pH = 7±0.2. The following steps were the same as the three-step precipitation method. The catalyst was named co-CZA-7%ZrO2. A series of CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts with various of Cu content (50%, 55%, 60%, 65% and 70%) were prepared by two-step precipitation. The detailed procedure was described in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Characterization Cu, Zn, Al and Zr metal contents in catalysts were determined by using inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Spector, Germany). A fully automatic gas analyzer (Autosorb iQ, Antonpa, USA) was used to measure the specific surface area. Firstly, the catalysts were degassed at 200 °C for 4 h. The specific surface area and porosity were determined by N2 physisorption at liquid nitrogen temperature, and the BET method were used to obtain specific surface area. The crystalline structure was measured using an X-ray powder diffractometer (D8 Advance DaVinci, Bruker, Germany) with a radiation source of Cu Kα (λ = 2.0463 Å) and a scanning range of 20°∼80°. The surface valence states of elements were measured by using an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AXIS SUPRA, Kratos, UK), equipped with an Al Kα radiation (E = 1486.7 eV) excitation source, and all binding energies were calibrated with C 1 s (284.6 eV). The samples were reduced at 250 °C for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature, purged with N2 for 3 h, packed into a sealed bag filled with N2, and immediately sent to the sample cell for testing. The catalyst morphology was observed by transmission electron microscopy (JEOL F200, JEOL, Japan). The acceleration voltage was 200 kV. The reduced samples were immediately ultrasonically dispersed with ethanol and then dripped onto an ultra-thin carbon film. The sample was transferred to a sealed bag filled with N2 and immediately sent to the sample cell for characterization. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) were carried out on automatic temperature programmed chemisorbed instrument (VDSorb-91i, Vodo, China). In the H2-TPR analysis, 50 mg of calcined sample was weighed and placed in 30 mL/min 10% H2/Ar gas stream, and heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. In CO2-TPD measurement, the calcined sample (0.1 g) was reduced at 250 °C in 30 mL/min 10% H2/Ar atmosphere for 1 h, cooled to 30 °C, exposed to 30 mL/min 10% CO2/Ar for 1 h, and the surface was purged with 30 mL/min Ar for 30 min. Then it was heated to 800 °C at 10 °C/min. Mass spectrometer (MASS SPECTROMETER, HIDEN ANALYTICAL, UK) was used to analyze the exhaust products of chemisorbed apparatus. The H2-TPD experiment was the same as the above steps, except that the adsorbed gas was changed to 10% H2/Ar. The N2O titration was conducted using a using a Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920 system (Autochem II 2920, Micromeritics, USA). The associated experimental procedures and calculation details are described in the Supporting Information. The changes of intermediate species on the catalyst surface during the reaction were studied by infrared spectroscopy (Nicolet 6700, Thermo, USA). The catalysts were reduced in 10% H2/Ar (10 mL/min) at atmospheric pressure and 250 °C for 1 h and followed by a He purge for 30 min. The catalysts were firstly exposed to 75% H2/CO2 (8 mL/min) atmosphere at 250 °C for 40 min and the inlet was switched to 75% H2/He (8 mL/min) and maintained at the same temperature for another 30 min. The changes of intermediate species on the catalyst surface were recorded. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic evaluation in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was conducted in a tubular, stainless steel, and fixed bed reactor. 0.1 g of catalyst with particle sizes ranging from 40 to 60 mesh was loaded in the middle of the reactor through a stainless-steel lining and quartz cotton. Before each reaction, the catalyst was reduced in 10 mL/min H2 at 250 °C for 3 h. When the temperature is cooled below 100 °C, the reactor is pressurized to 5 MPa, and the feedstock gas of 72% H2/24% CO2/N2 was introduced, and the gas hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 20,000 mL/(gcat·h). The gas products at the reactor outlet are analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC-2014, Shimadzu), the chromatography was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). The outlet product of the reactor was connected to the gas chromatography through a 120 °C heating strip to avoid methanol liquefaction. XCO2 represents the CO2 conversion, SMeOH refers to the selectivity of methanol, STYCH3OH (gCH3OH/(kgcat·h)) is space time yield of methanol. The following is calculation formula: (1) X CO 2 = F CO out + F ( CH 3 OH ) out F ( CO 2 ) out + F CO out + F ( CH 3 OH ) out × 100 % (2) S CH 3 OH = F ( CH 3 OH)out F CO out + F ( CH 3 OH ) out × 100 % (3) STY CH 3 OH = F ( CO 2 ) in ∙ X CO 2 ∙ S CH 3 OH ∙ M CH 3 OH 22.4 m F represents volumetric flow rate. For example, F(CO2) in and F(CO2) out represents the CO2 flow rate at the inlet and outlet; M is relative molecular weight, m refers to the catalyst mass. The carbon balance in the catalytic evaluation is ≥97%. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance for CO2 hydrogenation Prior to investigate the impact of ZrO2 and Al2O3 composite on the catalyst structure and reactivity in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, we firstly optimized the content of CuO (50–70% mass fraction) and of ZnO (20–40% mass fraction) in CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) through studying the effect on the methanol production. The mass fraction of Al2O3 in CZA was initially fixed at 10%, similar to that of the commercial Cu-based catalyst for methanol synthesis. It was found that the sample with 60%CuO and 30%ZnO exhibited the highest conversion of CO2, largest space-time yield of methanol (STY) and similar methanol selectivity relative to other samples in the investigated conditions (Fig. S1). We can note that the STY value achieved over the CZA catalyst is higher than that of the commercial Cu-based catalyst (Fig. S2). Based on the optimized ternary CZA catalyst (60%CuO and 30%ZnO), a series of CuO/ZnO/Al2O3/ZrO2 (denoted as CZA-xZrO2) catalysts with different contents of ZrO2 and Al2O3 were prepared using a three-step precipitation method, where the total content of Al2O3 and ZrO2 was maintained at 10%. The effect of ZrO2 and Al2O3 amounts on the catalytic activity ( Fig. 1a) exhibits that the conversion of CO2 increased to the maximum with increasing the addition of ZrO2 to 7%, and then decreased over the ternary Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 (CZZ) catalyst in the temperature range of 200–250 °C. The CO2 conversion increased gradually with increasing the temperature from 200 °C to 250 °C. At 200 °C, the conversion rate of the CZA-7%ZrO2 catalyst increased by 14% compared with the CZA catalyst (Fig. 1a). The presence of ZrO2 resulted in a small reduction in the selectivity of methanol in the range of 200–240 °C (Fig. 1b). The selectivity of methanol decreased gradually with increasing the temperature (200→250 °C) due to higher temperature promoted the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction to CO [25]. When the content of ZrO2 was 7%, the STY of methanol also increased at higher temperature (200→250 °C) for the sample (Fig. 1c). The presence of 2–7%ZrO2 in the modified samples enhanced the methanol production relative to CZA. The STY of methanol underwent the largest value over the 7%ZrO2 sample and decreased over the CZZ catalyst in the range of 200–250 °C (Fig. 1d). Compared with the ternary CZA and CZZ catalyst, the STY of methanol achieved over CZA-7%ZrO2 increased dramatically. Therefore, the presence of ZrO2 and Al2O3 could improve the conversion and the STY of methanol. Moreover, we can note that the CZA-7%ZrO2 catalyst was more active than co-CZA-7%ZrO2 prepared by coprecipitation and the industrial catalyst (Fig. S2). We also summarized the catalytic performance of the Cu-based catalysts reported in previous studies (Table S1), which show that the catalytic activity of CZA-7%ZrO2 prepared in this work exceeds the majority of the Cu catalysts under similar reaction conditions. The effect of space velocities on the catalytic performance of CZA-7%ZrO2 (Fig. S3a) shows increased conversion of CO2 with decreased methanol selectivity at lower space velocities, which indicate that the low space velocities are conducive to the RWGS reaction. The STY of methanol went up with increasing the space velocities (Fig. S3b). The long-term stability of CZA-7%ZrO2 catalyst was carried out. The catalyst retained stable within 300 h after an initial loss of conversion, methanol selectivity and STY (Fig. S4), showing good stability. 3.2 Structural features ICP was used to measure the elemental content, which are close to the target values ( Table 1). The adsorption and desorption isotherms of all the catalysts exhibit type IV hysteresis loop (Fig. S5), indicative of mesoporous structure. The presence of ZrO2 increased the specific surface area (Table 1). The XRD analysis ( Fig. 2a) reveals the calcined catalyst CZA-xZrO2 are characterized by CuO (2θ = 35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7° and 61.5°) and ZnO (2θ = 31.8°, 34.4° and 36.3°). With the increased content of ZrO2 and decreased content of Al2O3, the characteristic diffraction peaks of CuO firstly decreased and then increased. The grain size of CuO firstly decreases and then increases [26]. The reduced CZA-xZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 2b) display metallic Cu0 phase (2θ = 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.1°). No characteristic diffraction peak of CuO and Cu2O was observed, suggesting CuO was fully reduced to Cu0 [27]. Besides, the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnO (100), (002) and (101) at 2θ = 31.7°, 34.4° and 36.3° were also observed. But there is no diffraction peak of Al2O3 or ZrO2 in the calcined and reduced catalysts, suggesting Al2O3 and ZrO2 are amorphous and/or highly dispersed [28]. The Cu grain sizes calculated by Scherrer equation (shown in Table 1) reveal the average size of Cu crystallites decreases with the increase of ZrO2 content, and increases when ZrO2 completely replaces Al2O3. This indicates that the co-presence of ZrO2 and Al2O3 can promote the dispersion of Cu with forming small Cu particles. The dispersion of Cu (DCu), exposed surface area of Cu (SCu) and the size of Cu grains (dCu) were calculated by N2O-titration (Table 1). The DCu values are in the range of 12.6–23.7%. With increasing the ZrO2 content (0→7%), the Cu dispersion gradually increases to the maximum (23.7%) over the CZA-7%ZrO2 sample, and decreases over CZZ, which is consistent with the XRD analysis. Both SCu and dCu undergo a similar variation trend with ZrO2 content. This suggests an appropriate amount of ZrO2 and Al2O3 plays a significant role in the Cu dispersion and exposed surface area of Cu. The morphology of the reduced the CZA-xZrO2 catalysts was analyzed by TEM (Fig. S6). The catalyst presented irregular spherical, massive and rod-like particles with a size of about 300 nm, and the particles were stacked with each other, resulting in large shadows. EDS-mapping was used to observe the distribution of Cu, Zn, Al, and Zr, as shown in Fig. S7. Cu, Zn, Al and Zr were uniformly distributed without obvious aggregation. The high-resolution TEM analysis was used to observe the microstructure of the reduced CZA-xZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, lattice fringes of 0.182 nm and 0.208 nm were observed in the reduced CZA-xZrO2 catalysts, corresponding to the Cu (200) and (111) facet. Lattice fringes of 0.281 nm were also observed, corresponding to ZnO (100) [29]. In the TEM images of CZA and CZA-7%ZrO2, Cu and ZnO are in close contact, favoring the formation of Cu-ZnO interface. No lattice fringe of Al2O3 and ZrO2 was found over all the catalysts, which verify that Al2O3 and ZrO2 are amorphous. It is reported that the Cu-ZrO2 interface act as the active site for generation of methanol [30,31]. 3.3 The reducibility of the CZA-xZrO2 catalysts and XPS analysis H2-TPR was carried out to investigate the reducibility of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4, there are three peaks (denoted as α, β, γ), suggesting different types of CuO species. The α peak is attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO particles [24], and the content of highly dispersed CuO species increases gradually after the addition of ZrO2. The asymmetric β peak as the primary H2 consumption signal in the middle temperature range can be attributed to the reduction of dispersed CuO [32], and the peak temperature decreases gradually with the increase of ZrO2 content (0→7%). This suggests the presence of ZrO2 favors the reduction of CuO due to the weaker interaction between CuO and other oxides that weakens the strength of the Cu-O bond [16]. When all Al2O3 is replaced by ZrO2, the β peak temperature increases, which may be caused by the decrease of CuO dispersion. The γ peak, only detectable over CZA with weak signal, can be attributed to the reduction of large and/or bulky CuO particles [18]. and the presence of ZrO2 causes the bulk CuO to disappear. Therefore, the appropriate amount of ZrO2 can promote the dispersion of Cu and reduce the particle size. The Cu 2p XPS analysis of the reduced samples ( Fig. 5a) shows Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 orbits at 952.3 eV and 932.3 eV [33]. No detectable satellite peak of Cu2+ indicate that surface Cu2+ species was reduced to Cu0 or Cu+. Since the difficulty in distinguishing the surface Cu0 and Cu+ species in XPS due to the partially overlapped signals, Auger electron spectroscopy was conducted for further analysis of surface Cu oxidation states [34]. Surface Cu0 and Cu+ species are characterized by binding energy at 568 eV and 570 eV in the Cu LMM spectra (Fig. 5b) [35]. The majority of surface Cu species in the reduced CZA and CZZ samples present as the Cu+ species; while the content of surface Cu0 was enhanced after addition of appropriate amounts of ZrO2 (Table S2). The XPS signals for Zn 2p (Fig. 5c) exhibit significantly split spin-orbits (Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2) with the corresponding binding energy at 1044.7 eV and 1021.6 eV [36]. Since chemical state differentiation for Zn is difficult with XPS only, and the Zn LMM Auger region (Fig. 5d) is more sensitive to surface Zn0 species identified at BE = 495.5 eV and surface Zn2+ component at 498 eV [37]. A calculation of the amount of surface Zn species (Table. S2) finds a small fraction of Zn0 that does not change with the ZrO2 content. The XPS signals (Fig. S8) for Zr 3d3/2 (184.4 eV) and Zr 3d5/2 (181.7 eV) intensified with increasing the ZrO2 content, but with no peak shift [33], implying no dramatic variation in the valance states for surface Zr species. 3.4 Adsorption behavior of H2 and CO2 Fig. 6(a, b) displays the H2-TPD and MS-H2 profiles, where three H2 desorption peaks were recorded. The low temperature peak at ca. 80 °C for all the samples is due to the desorption of hydrogen adsorbed on the surface of Cu [24]. A broad desorption signal with the peak maxima at 300 °C can be linked to hydrogen desorption on the surface of large Cu particles or ZnO [38,39]. The H2 desorption peak beyond 500 °C, observed clearly over CZA-5%ZrO2 and CZA-7%ZrO2 (featured with high Cu dispersion relative to other samples), may be associated with spillover hydrogen. It has been reported that the high dispersion of Cu is beneficial to forming a large number of Cu-ZnO interface, resulting in a strong H2 spillover effect [40,41]. The CO2 adsorption capacity of all the catalysts was determined by CO2-TPD. CO2-TPD and MS-CO2 profiles were shown in Fig. 6(c, d). The positions of CO2 signals in MS basically correspond to those in the CO2-TPD profile. There are three main CO2 desorption peaks at different (low, middle and high) temperature regions in the profiles, which could be assigned to weak (α peak), moderate (β peak), and strong (γ peak) basic sites [42]. The weak basic site corresponds to the OH- group, the moderate basic site corresponds to the metal oxygen pair (Zn-O, Al-O, Zr-O), and the strong basic site corresponds to the low-coordinated oxygen atom [39]. We can note that a significant amount of moderate basic sites is generated when both Al2O3 and ZrO2 present relative to either Al2O3 or ZrO2 alone in the catalyst. In addition, the proportion of strong basic sites is correspondingly reduced with a gradual increase of ZrO2 content and a decrease of Al2O3, where there is almost no strong basic site observable over the CZZ sample. This suggest the formation of strong basic site is associated with Al2O3, and the presence of ZrO2 and Al2O3 facilitate formation of moderate adsorption sites. 3.5 Correlations between activity and structural parameters The above experimental results demonstrate that the presence of both Al2O3 and ZrO2 significantly improves the CO2 conversion and STY of methanol, and the catalytic activity of CZA-7%ZrO2 was much higher than the samples with other contents of Al2O3 and ZrO2, the one prepared by coprecipitation and commercial catalyst. Based on the catalyst characterization analysis, the content of Al2O3 and ZrO2 definitely changes the structure and surface characteristics in term of Cu surface area, surface Cu valence distribution, surface basicity and capacity for reactant’s adsorption. In the existing literature, surface area of Cu (SCu) is important in determining the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts. The adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen generally occur at the Cu site, and the dissociated hydrogen spillovers to the Cu-oxide interface to participate in the surface reaction with the activated CO2* species. [20,24] As shown in Fig. 7a, the correlation of the exposed surface area of Cu with the content of ZrO2 shows a volcanic trend, where the surface area of Cu goes up to the largest value over CZA-7%ZrO2. In Fig. 7b, SCu is proportionally correlated with the conversion of CO2 under different reaction temperatures. This can be explained by the increased number of Cu active site, higher catalytic ability for the H2 dissociation and hydrogen overflow to the interface of Cu-oxide for hydrogenation of carbon-containing substances [43]. The exposed surface area of Cu indeed can impact the conversion of CO2 as reported elsewhere [44,45]. But the relationship is not linear, suggesting other factors besides SCu interfere with the CO2 conversion. The valence state of Cu has also been reported to affect the catalyst activity [35]. It is generally believed that in Cu-based catalysts, the adsorption and activation of H2 are completed on Cu0 [17]. The presence of Cu+ is conducive to the stability of the intermediate CH3O* and facilitates the conversion of CH3O* [46,47]. As shown in Fig. 8a, an increase in the ZrO2 content to 7% leads to a progressive enhancement in the proportion of surface Cu0 species with the largest ratio of Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) recorded over the CZA-7%ZrO2 catalyst. Meanwhile, a similar trend is observed in the correlation of the ZrO2 content with STY of methanol. We also conduct the analysis of the relationship between Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) and STY of methanol (Fig. 8b), revealing a dependence of methanol production on the distribution of surface Cu0 and Cu+ species. We note that a majority of Cu0 (>50%) and a small fraction of Cu+ shows high methanol formation rate. This is consistent with the result reported by Si et al. [7] (surface Cu0 species >57%) and Dong et al. [20] (Cu0/Cu+>4) that relatively high content of Cu0 exhibit increased activity in methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation. The surface basicity plays an important role in the adsorption and activation of CO2, which in turn impact the catalytic activity [48]. The modulation of composition results in significant variation in the catalysts’ basicity characteristics in terms of CO2 adsorption sites and strength. The presence of Al2O3 contributes to the formation of strong basic site associated with strong adsorption of CO2, and further inclusion of ZrO2 promotes the generation of moderate basic site. Weak basicity is almost free of influence from the change of the composite. Given the reaction temperature (200–250 °C) employed in this work, we consider the weak basic site cannot effectively adsorb and bind CO2 under reaction condition due to the facile desorption below 200 °C. This possibly contributes to the lowest conversion rate over the CZZ sample with the weak surface basicity as the dominate sites for CO2 adsorption. The adsorbed CO2 species at the moderate and strong basic site are more likely to participate in the reaction. But too strong interaction between intermediates/products and adsorption sites potentially does not favor the desorption, resulting in occupation of active sites. The relatively low activity for the CZA catalyst perhaps is due to a considerable number of strong basicity with insufficient moderate site. The presence of significantly moderate adsorption sites over the CZA-ZrO2 samples contributes to the increased conversion rate of CO2, but there is no proportional relationship of moderate basic sites with the catalytic activity. 3.6 Reaction mechanism In situ diffuse reflection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was used to observe the evolution of intermediate species during the reaction on CZA and CZA-7%ZrO2. The catalyst was reduced in-situ in the sample cell and then the feed gas was passed into the cell at 250 °C and the ambient pressure. In the spectra over CZA and CZA-7%ZrO2, the characteristic bands of the formate (*HCOO) species at 1590 cm−1, 1374 cm−1 and 2882 cm−1 ( Fig. 9) can be corresponded to the asymmetric OCO stretching νas(OCO), symmetric OCO stretching vibrations νs(OCO) and the CH stretching ν(CH), respectively [49]. The signals observed at 2935 cm−1 and 2852 cm−1 correspond to νas(CH3) and νs(CH3) of the methoxy (*H3CO) species [30]. With the increase of reaction time, the signals of formate and methoxy group intensified due to the surface species accumulated, and reached a stability at 20 min. No *CO species (1900–2000 cm−1) was detected during the reaction. An additional band at 1346 cm−1 was recorded over CZA-7%ZrO2 [50], which is caused by the O-C-O vibration of the formate species on Cu [51]. The HCOO-Cu adsorption site was beneficial to the hydroconversion of formate and improves the conversion frequency of oxygen-containing intermediates on the catalyst [52]. After the reaction in 40 min, the samples were swept using 75% H2/He. The characteristic peak intensities for formate and methoxy gradually weakened (Fig. S9), suggesting the formate species is hydrogenated to methoxy, and further hydrogenated to methanol. In the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, there are two main reaction mechanisms, which are RWGS reaction pathway and formate pathway [10]. CO* is the main intermediate in the RWGS pathway, and methanol is produced from CO* hydrogenation. The formate pathway involves the conversion of CO2 to HCOO*, and further hydrogenation of HCOO* to H2COO*→H2CO*→H3CO*→CH3OH. During the reaction, formate and methoxyl species are mainly produced on the catalyst surface, and no CO* species are detected. So methoxy species are formed by hydrogenation of formate species. After switching to 75% H2/He gas, the formate and methoxyl species accumulated on the surface are converted through consecutive hydrogenation steps (HCOO* →H2CO* →H3CO*→CH3OH). Therefore, the CZA-xZrO2 catalyst follows the formate pathway in the methanol synthesis reaction. The CO in the reaction may be caused by the breakdown of formate [16]. 4 Conclusions A series of Cu/ZnO-based catalysts composed of mixed oxide (Al2O3 and ZrO2) are constructed through tuning the content by three-step precipitation. An appropriate amount of Al2O3 and ZrO2 in the catalyst can promote the dispersion of Cu, increase the exposed surface area of Cu, increase the content of Cu0, and promote the formation of moderate basic sites, thus improving the activity of the catalyst. The activity of the CZA-7%ZrO2 catalyst is the highest and much higher than that of the industrial catalyst. We find that the conversion rate of CO2 is positively correlated with SCu, the relatively high content of Cu0 showed higher activity, and the increase of the number of moderate basic sites contributes to the improvement of CO2 conversion rate. The conversion of CO2 to methanol principally follows the formate−methoxy pathway. CRediT authorship contribution statement Li Jing: Formal analysis, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts have been widely applied as industrial catalysts for methanol synthesis from syngas, but suffers low activity for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. This study establishes highly active Cu catalysts through modulation of the composite of Al2O3 and ZrO2 in Cu/ZnO-based catalysts. The composition of Al2O3 and ZrO2 impacts the Cu dispersion, exposed surface area of Cu, the Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio and surface basicity. An appropriate content of Al2O3 and ZrO2 presents the higher Cu surface area, desirable ratio of Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) and moderate-strong basic sites for effective CO2 adsorption/activation, giving rise to higher space-time yield of methanol (up to 648 gCH3OH·kgcat −1·h−1) than the commercial Cu catalyst. STY of methanol can be correlated with Cu surface area and Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio under the investigated conditions. The mechanistic analysis demonstrates that surface formate and methoxy species are the major intermediates. The methanol formation principally follows the formate-methoxy intermediate pathway.
coredata.dc:title: Modulation of Al2O3 and ZrO2 composite in Cu/ZnO-based catalysts with enhanced performance for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
